captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

It&#39;s one of those times when the triple-A 
publishers are all tuckered out from

firing people and cleaning up that one bed 
they&#39;ve been repeatedly shitting lately,

so they have a bit of a sleep in their bed of 
shit and the indies can have a chance to shine.

And they certainly are shining right now as they 
stream out onto Steam like a glittering river

of urine. But as I played another five pixel art 
cyberpunk traversal-focussed Metroidvanias about

someone with teal-coloured hair, my thoughts 
kept returning to an indie game I tried on

my Wednesday stream a while back called Another 
Crab&#39;s Treasure. I was having trouble identifying

my feelings towards it, but then it hit me. 
Oh yeah. Enjoyment. I vaguely remember that.

I enjoyed Another Crab&#39;s Treasure and I want 
to play it some more. So I did. And I&#39;m gonna

do a proper review of Another Crab&#39;s Treasure, a 
name that going forward I shall shorten to Crabs.

Crabs has really grown on me. I&#39;ve been saying on 
social media, blimey, Crabs has really gotten me

by the hairs. I&#39;ve been saying to my wife, sorry 
we haven&#39;t had a chance to be intimate, lately,

darling, I&#39;m just really struggling with Crabs, 
lately. That and my advanced syphilis. Okay,

I&#39;m done with my early 90s too hot for TV late 
night stand-up bit, let&#39;s talk about the game.

Another Crab&#39;s Treasure is first and 
foremost a soulslike, but astonishingly,

isn&#39;t about a grim dark fantasy world creeping 
inexorably towards ruin and apocalypse, but

about a cheerful cartoon undersea city of talking 
marine life, creeping inexorably towards ruin and

apocalypse. We play as Kril, a timid little hermit 
crab in a tide pool leading an idyllic life of

hiding under rocks trying not to be delicious to 
seagulls when an evil taxman takes his shell and

he&#39;s forced to venture into the larger ocean, 
finding it mired in corruption, bureaucracy

and non-biodegradable commercial goods. We go 
through the usual dance of coming up with new

names for the standard Soulslike trappings, 
the way Bloodborne basically just changed

&quot;soul&quot; to &quot;blood&quot; with the Microsoft Word find and 
replace function. So instead of estus it&#39;s kelp,

instead of bonfires it&#39;s purple shells and instead 
of souls for buying things and levelling up it&#39;s

microplastics. Which is both a fun gag and 
a timely environmental message. Part of what

drew me to Crabs is the surprisingly witty writing 
and surprisingly cynical tone for a game about an

adorable cartoon crab with a shrill, quavering 
voice like Ash Ketchum talking into a fan.

On that subject it&#39;s probably the most 
flamboyantly voice acted indie game I&#39;ve played

in a while, everyone&#39;s really got their Hanna 
Barbera hats on. The first boss in particular,

I have no idea how you could get a more 
genuinely furious-sounding performance out

of an actor without spending the entire 
studio session stealing coins out of his

wallet and flicking them at his bollocks. So 
that&#39;s one way to bypass my soulslike fatigue,

but the most sure fire method is to really mix 
up the established mechanics. Most soulslikes,

for example, use that tiresome old parry mechanic 
of pressing the block button just as you get hit,

but Another Crabs Treasure has an original, 
interesting, sexy alternative wherein you

RELEASE the block button just as you get 
hit. Steady on, Another Crab&#39;s Treasure,

the last time anyone innovated that much they 
got burned at the stake for witchcraft. The

core combat does have a very overt focus on 
blocking, if that weren&#39;t already obvious

from the release parry thing or the main 
character&#39;s status as a tiny frightened sea

animal whose main popular characteristic 
is their ability to hide under things.

No shade, I&#39;m just saying if you were bitten by 
a radioactive one you wouldn&#39;t be fighting much

crime but you&#39;d gain a considerable insight into 
your neighbour&#39;s dustbins. And then there&#39;s the

shell mechanic. As befits a hermit crab, 
you have the ability to grab any tin can,

fast food container or menstrual cup that&#39;s 
lying around and use it as a shell, each having

different strengths and weaknesses and special 
attacks attached. The tin can is more durable

but slows down your dodge roll, the menstrual cup 
is quicker but breaks more easily and will cause

your restaurant to fail a government hygiene 
inspection, etc. What I like about the shell

mechanic is that it boils down all that tiresome 
faffing about with equipment that was part of the

Dark Souls experience - ooh, could I put on some 
gauntlets and still get away with midrolling,

do these pauldrons bring out my sunken eye 
sockets, whoops, need to jump over something,

better strip down to my nasty underpants and 
try to remember which of my seventeen pairs

of trousers I left my car keys in - here it&#39;s 
just one button press. Shell on, shell off.

Like all great game mechanics it knocks down 
multiple pins at once - it fits with the theme,

encourages experimenting with gameplay styles 
and adds a collectathon element for the psychos.

Having said that, encouraging experimentation is 
all very well but sooner or later the scientific

process ends and you have to leave academia and 
get a real job. And a relatively short way into

the game I found a bit of old pipe with high 
defense, and used it for basically the whole

rest of the game. Might&#39;ve been a mistake to 
let me insure my bit of old pipe for a small

fee so I could respawn with it every time - 
incidentally the word &quot;respawn&quot; has suddenly

become a lot more apropos, hasn&#39;t it - &#39;cos it 
turned the entire shell mechanic into a hollow,

erm, epidermis of its former self. And it&#39;s one 
of several questionable design decisions on the

game&#39;s part. There&#39;s also a platforming focus 
so the environments are having a bit of a love

affair with bottomless pits - don&#39;t gaze 
into the abyss, Another Crab&#39;s Treasure,

the abyss is pretty emotionally unavailable 
these days - and I was falling down them

from misjudging the recoil on some of 
my attacks more than I care to admit,

but after a while I noticed that as I was 
falling down I could pause, equip the one

accessory that removes all penalties for falling 
into pits, then unequip it again as soon I was

safely back on solid ground, and that really 
felt like something I wasn&#39;t supposed to do.

So as soulslikes go it&#39;s pretty easy, especially 
after you&#39;ve gotten to grips with parrying and

bought out the skill tree, but you know what, I&#39;m 
fed up to the hollow eye sockets with everything

trying to out-souls the Soulses just by getting 
harder all the time, when there are so many other

ways. An engaging story full of characters with 
nice, clear motives, that&#39;s a good start. And

being actually funny. I mean, if slaughtering 
mindless, once-intelligent beings en masse in

a world inexorably creeping towards doom isn&#39;t 
a good time for giggles, I don&#39;t know what is.

So I like having Crabs, it scratches an itch in 
a place I never knew I had, ironically. For all

its points of dodgy design and slightly annoying 
camera, it&#39;s compelling and imaginative and it has

a heart of delicious lemony flesh in a yielding 
crunchy carapace. I mean, it&#39;s a cartoon game

basically in the setting of Spongebob Squarepants 
whose story deals with themes of despotism,

corruption, class division, exploitation of the 
poor, disillusionment, environmental collapse,

there&#39;s a bit where giant creepy spiders with 
telephones on their heads fire lasers at you,

and the final message of the story is &quot;nothing&#39;s 
getting better so fuck it.&quot; And that&#39;s pretty

sound philosophy for a crab. An ambitious crab 
and a cowardly crab make an equally tasty bisque.
